profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Amherst, Mass., April 27, 1778; attended the common schools; learned the trade of shoemaker and engaged in that business in Worthington, Mass.; moved to New York City and thence to Georgia, where he engaged in the mercantile business until 1807; returned to New York City in 1807 and engaged in the leather business; member of the State assembly in 1822; member of the board of aldermen 1828-1830; mayor of New York City in 1833; declined to be a candidate for reelection; elected as a Jacksonian to the Twenty-fourth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Campbell P. White and served from November 4, 1835, to March 3, 1837; was not a candidate for renomination in 1836; retired in 1836; moved to Geneva, N.Y.; died in Geneva, N.Y., August 21, 1841; interment in the Washington Street Cemetery.

researchRecord.name: 1804-1868, 20 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The collection of Gideon Lee includes correspondence of a personal and business nature. The collections also contains family correspondence, 1806-1839; papers concerning the New York City fire in 1835; and marriage register as mayor, 1833-1834.

researchRecord.name: 1807-1839, 165 items.
researchRecord.description: The letters are almost entirely received by Gideon Lee, mostly from constituents. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Richard W. Simpson Papers ca. 1814-1893, 0.50 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: The collection documents the legal, financial, personal, and family affairs of Gideon Lee, for his deceased wife Floride and their daughter, Isabella Lee.

researchRecord.name: 1823-1837, 32 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers consist of letters to Gideon Lee, mostly while he was serving as a New York State Assemblyman in 1823, and later, in 1835, as a Member of the House of Representatives. They are generally requests for assistance from his constituents in New York City.

researchRecord.name: n.d., 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Gideon Lee, Mayor of New York, to an unidentified recipient containing instructions regarding his newspaper subscription.
